children: A 19-year-old woman with epilepsy and learning disabilities is evaluated for the skin findings
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The elliptical hypopigmented macule in this image is recognized as the ash-leaf spot associated with tuberous sclerosis, a congenital neurocutaneous syndrome. Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a genetic disorder with mutations in the tumor-suppressing genes
TSC1
or
TSC2

and resulting tumors in many organs, primarily the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, skin, and lungs. Most patients have cutaneous findings, including hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf spots), angiofibromas, Shagreen patches, and fibrous forehead plaques. Epilepsy is present in most patients with tuberous sclerosis, and cognitive deficits, learning disabilities, and behavioral problems are also common.

objective.__html: Recognize the ash-leaf spot and its association with tuberous sclerosis complex.

children: A 61-year-old man with difficult-to-control hypertension is evaluated for recurrent episodes of "flash" pulmonary edema. Renal artery magnetic resonance imaging
angiography
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is renal artery stenosis. The magnetic resonance renal angiogram shows bilateral ostial renal artery stenosis as the result of atherosclerotic renal vascular disease. Three randomized controlled trials (STAR, ASTRAL, and CORAL) failed to show that renal artery angioplasty confers additional benefit above optimal medical therapy for patients with atherosclerotic renovascular disease who have stable kidney function. Patients who may benefit from percutaneous angioplasty and stenting or surgical intervention include those who present with a short duration of hypertension; fail medical therapy; or have severe hypertension or recurrent flash pulmonary edema, refractory heart failure, acute kidney injury following treatment with an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker, or progressive impaired kidney function.

title: Question 3

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension and progressive left flank pain.
Abdominal CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms identified on CT is polycystic kidney disease. Abdominal CT in this patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease shows enlarged kidneys with multiple bilateral cysts (appearing as hypodense lesions), with disruption of the architecture of the left kidney due to large cysts that make it minimally recognizable on imaging. The extent of cyst formation may be appreciated in the coronal view as shown above. The image
shown
below illustrates the gross pathology of polycystic kidneys.

objective.__html: Identify the CT findings characteristic of polycystic kidney disease.

figureCredits: Image in critique reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated for acute kidney injury.
Urinalysis results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is acute tubular necrosis. This patient's urine sediment shows multiple large, granular, muddy brown casts, which are highly suggestive of acute tubular necrosis. The backbone of all urine casts is a matrix composed of Tamm-Horsfall protein (uromodulin). These cylindrical casts form in the distal tubular lumen. Necrotic cells and debris, originating in the more proximal parts of the nephron, are also present within the casts. The severity of acute kidney injury correlates with the number of casts and presence of renal tubular epithelial cells.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute tubular necrosis on the basis of muddy brown casts seen on urinalysis.

title: Question 5

children: A 69-year-old woman is evaluated during a wellness visit. The average of three blood pressure measurements is 150/80 mm Hg.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is most compatible with the funduscopic findings shown?
Hypertensive retinopathy is most compatible with the funduscopic findings shown. This funduscopic examination
shows
the generalized arteriolar narrowing (
white arrows
) compared with venule diameter (
black arrows

) characteristic of hypertensive retinopathy. The degree of retinal arterial narrowing is assessed by comparing arteriolar diameter relative to retinal venule diameter (arteriole-to-venule ratio); venule diameters do not vary substantially in most patients with hypertension. An arteriole-to-venule ratio less than 1 suggests relative arteriolar narrowing; this patient's arteriole-to-venule ratio is 0.63. Arteriolar narrowing is a predictor of future development of hypertension and increased risk for stroke. Evidence also indicates that arteriolar narrowing is associated with coronary artery disease and kidney damage.

figureCredits: Images reproduced with permission from Wong TY, Klein R, Sharrett AR, et al; Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities Study. Retinal arteriolar diameter and risk for hypertension.

children: Ann Intern Med
A 67-year-old man is evaluated for a new rash and acute kidney injury following coronary catheterization.
The rash is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acute kidney injury?

Disseminated atheroemboli is the most likely cause of this patient's acute kidney injury as evidenced by livedo reticularis (a lacy network of bluish red vessels, usually seen on the legs). Patients with atherosclerotic disease who undergo an invasive vascular procedure, such as vascular surgery or angiography, are at increased risk for atheroemboli-induced acute kidney injury (cholesterol emboli). Atheroembolic events can occur spontaneously or several days to weeks after manipulation of the aorta. Plaque rupture causes cholesterol embolization to distal small- and medium-sized arteries, resulting in ischemia with end-organ damage. In addition to the kidneys, atheroemboli can affect the arteries in the skin, muscle, gastrointestinal tract, liver, eyes, and central nervous system. Apart from livedo reticularis, physical examination findings may also include Hollenhorst plaques on funduscopic examination (yellow refractile emboli within retinal arteries), ulcerations, and blue toe syndrome caused by ischemia.

objective.__html: Diagnose disseminated atheroemboli as a cause of acute kidney injury.

children: A 41-year-old woman is evaluated for the abrupt onset of hypertension. A renal
angiography
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is fibromuscular dysplasia. The patient's renal angiogram shows typical fibromuscular disease manifested by the "string of beads" sign. Renal duplex ultrasonography is a reasonable imaging modality if performed by an experienced sonographer. Magnetic resonance or CT angiography have higher diagnostic utility but are potentially harmful in patients with severe chronic kidney disease given the risk for contrast nephropathy and gadolinium-induced nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.
A 33-year-old man is evaluated for asymptomatic microscopic hematuria. Urinalysis is performed.
Urine microscopy is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Glomerulonephritis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient's urinalysis shows an erythrocyte cast and indicates glomerular disease. Erythrocytes may be distinct or incorporated into a homogenous mass. The most characteristic feature of an erythrocyte cast, when present, is its orange-red appearance. The glomerular hematuria seen in the nephritic syndrome can be distinguished from other causes of urinary tract bleeding by the presence of either dysmorphic erythrocytes (resulting from distortion that occurs as they pass through the glomerular basement membrane and then along the renal tubules) or erythrocyte casts on urine microscopy. Red blood cells lack a nucleus, which helps to distinguish them for other nucleated cell types. Common features of glomerulonephritis are hematuria (microscopic or macroscopic) and proteinuria, with the more severe forms typically including hypertension, edema, and kidney dysfunction (elevated serum creatinine).

objective.__html: Diagnose glomerulonephritis based on an erythrocyte cast seen on urinalysis.

children: A 46-year-old man is evaluated following an episode of nephrolithiasis. He has yet to pass the kidney stone.
Urinalysis results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is uric acid stone. Uric acid crystals can take on a variety of appearances, such as rhomboids, barrels, rosettes, needles, or hexagonal plates. Urate crystals can be a normal constituent of the urine but are also commonly associated with urate nephrolithiasis or acute urate nephropathy.
A 63-year-old man is evaluated for chronic kidney disease.
Abdominal CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The abdominal CT scan demonstrates hydronephrosis of the right kidney. There is also cortical thinning of the right kidney, best
seen
on coronal imaging, suggesting that the hydronephrosis has been chronic.

Ultrasonography is the preferred initial diagnostic study for most patients to evaluate for hydronephrosis, although CT may be indicated if an obstructing stone is suspected or in patients with anatomically abnormal kidneys (such as in polycystic kidney disease) in whom ultrasonography results may be difficult to interpret. CT may also be indicated in patients with hydronephrosis detected by ultrasonography to help define the cause of hydronephrosis, such as distal ureteral obstruction, that may be more effectively seen on CT.

objective.__html: Identify the CT findings characteristic of hydronephrosis.

children: A 62-year-old woman with end-stage kidney disease is evaluated for the painful skin lesion
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is calciphylaxis (also known as calcific uremic arteriopathy), which manifests in later stages as extremely painful areas of necrosis, as seen in this patient. Earlier stages may appear as livedo reticularis or painful erythematous or violaceous nodules. Calciphylaxis is most commonly seen in persons with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) on dialysis or advanced chronic kidney disease with an elevated calcium-phosphorous product greater than 70 mg
/dL

. Parathyroid hormone levels are often dramatically elevated as a secondary process in ESKD. Although the precise mechanism is not fully elucidated, patients with ESKD exhibit abnormalities in the endothelial cells, which allow for an abnormal deposition of calcium within the lumen of the dermal arterioles. As the calcium deposition increases, small thromboses form that lead to ischemia and infarctions of the overlying tissue. The tissue becomes necrotic, painful, and a potential source for secondary infection that may lead to sepsis and death. Treatment is usually supportive with pain control. Aggressive control of calcium, phosphorus, and intact parathyroid hormone is recommended.
A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for flank pain. Focused point-of-care ultrasonography of the kidney is performed.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is hydronephrosis. This clip shows evidence of hydronephrosis, with dilation of the renal calyces appearing as anechoic regions in the middle of the kidney. They may be differentiated from kidney cysts by their ability to be "connected" with movement of the probe.

Ultrasonography is the most commonly used kidney imaging modality. It is easily available, safe, and relatively inexpensive. Ultrasonography can demonstrate hydronephrosis, kidney size and cortical thickness, echogenicity, and presence of cysts and tumors. Echogenicity is the ability of a tissue to “bounce back” or return the ultrasound signal and is recognized as brighter shades on the sonogram image. Echogenicity is nonspecific but implies acute or chronic parenchymal disease. Absence of hydronephrosis quickly rules out obstruction in most cases.
An 81-year-old woman is evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections and staghorn calculi.
Urinalysis results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's renal calculi?

The most likely cause of this patient's renal calculi is struvite. Struvite crystals typically have a “coffin lid” appearance. Struvite stones occur in the presence of urea-splitting bacteria, such as
Proteus
Klebsiella
, or, less frequently,
Pseudomonas

species. These bacteria split urea into ammonium, which markedly increases urine pH and results in the precipitation of magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite); the urine pH will be greater than 7.5. Struvite stones commonly produce staghorn calculi (stones that bridge two or more renal calyces) and occur most frequently in older women with chronic urinary tract infections. Because struvite stones are large and grow rapidly, they do not pass into the ureter to cause pain typical of smaller stones.

title: Question 14

children: A 56-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is evaluated for rapidly progressive proteinuric kidney disease. Kidney biopsy is
performed
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is diabetic nephropathy as evidenced by Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules seen on this patient's biopsy. Diabetic nephropathy manifests initially as moderately increased albuminuria (microalbuminuria). Over time, progressive proteinuria is followed by a decline in glomerular filtration rate, with progression to later stages of chronic kidney disease and end-stage kidney disease. The diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy is usually made clinically in the presence of hallmark features: proteinuric chronic kidney disease in a patient with long-standing diabetes and evidence of other complications (microvascular and/or macrovascular) of disease. If the clinical presentation is not entirely consistent with diabetic nephropathy, a kidney biopsy is performed. The biopsy finding of nodular mesangial sclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules) with glomerular and tubular basement thickening, in the absence of immune deposits, is the classic description of diabetic nephropathy.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 52-year-old asymptomatic man is evaluated during a wellness examination.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is retinal arteriosclerosis. The optic fundus shows changes of arteriosclerosis, which is characterized by arteriovenous nicking and arteriolar narrowing. Nicking is defined as the disappearance of a short segment of the venule where it is crossed by the arteriole and by a 90-degree-angle crossing of the arterioles and venules. The
white arrow
in the image
shown
identifies an area of nicking. Narrowed arterioles may appear as a "copper wire." Retinal arteriosclerotic changes are seen in hypertensive retinopathy.
A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive edema and proteinuria. A urinalysis is performed, and this finding is
observed
under polarized light.
This patient's urine finding is most consistent with which of the following diagnoses?

This patient's urine finding is most consistent with the nephrotic syndrome. The urine finding depicts the typical "Maltese cross" appearance of oval fat bodies. Oval fat bodies are a hallmark finding in the nephrotic syndrome, and the Maltese cross pattern is seen only under polarized light. Patients typically describe slowly progressive edema, and laboratory testing reveals proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia; serum creatinine is rarely elevated.
A 39-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension, proteinuria and elevated serum creatinine, and a painful rash, as
shown
. Results of hepatitis C virus testing are positive.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is cryoglobulinemia, a type of small vessel vasculitis. A palpable, nonblanching, purpuric rash is frequently present on the lower extremities. This patient has stellate, retiform purpura, and necrosis of the toes. Skin ulceration/necrosis is often seen in the setting of hyperviscosity.

Type 1 cryoglobulinemia is more commonly associated with lymphoproliferative disorders. Types II and III cryoglobulinemias are mixed cryoglobulinemias, and both can be associated with hepatitis C virus infection. Kidney manifestations can include elevated serum creatinine level, hypertension, proteinuria, and hematuria. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is usually noted on biopsy. Occasionally, a rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with crescent formation can occur. Treatment is directed at the underlying condition, but plasmapheresis to treat hyperviscosity syndrome and immunosuppressive medications for treatment of vasculitis may also be needed.

objective.__html: Diagnose cryoglobulinemia and associated kidney disease.

children: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, right flank pain, and dysuria.
Microscopic urinalysis results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Acute pyelonephritis is the most likely diagnosis. Leukocyte casts are most consistent with a tubulointerstitial disease or pyelonephritis, although they are occasionally seen in glomerular disorders. These casts are characterized by a tubular structure that contains cellular elements with clearly visible intracellular granules and multilobular nuclei. Pyelonephritis is a type of tubulointerstitial nephritis in which the interstitium is inflamed with neutrophilic infiltration as opposed to eosinophilic or lymphocytic infiltration, as occurs in cases of allergic interstitial nephritis.

objective.__html: Diagnose pyelonephritis based on a leukocyte cast seen on urinalysis.

children: A 36-year-old man is evaluated for nephrolithiasis.
Microscopic urinalysis results are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely composition of this patient's kidney stone?

Calcium oxalate is the most likely composition of this patient's kidney stone. The urine sediment shown contains envelope-shaped calcium oxalate dihydrate crystals, which are associated with hyperoxaluria and calcium oxalate stone formation. These crystals can also be seen with ethylene glycol ingestion.

objective.__html: Diagnose calcium oxalate stone formation on the basis of calcium oxalate crystals seen on urinalysis.

children: A 47-year-old woman is evaluated for acute onset of right flank pain and hematuria. Abdominal ultrasonography is
performed
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Polycystic kidney disease is the most likely diagnosis. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) manifests as large kidneys with multiple kidney cysts, and ultrasonography is the most common and least costly screening method. Ultrasonography criteria for diagnosing ADPKD are based on the number of visible cysts, the patient's age, and a family history of ADPKD.
ADPKD is the leading genetic cause of end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) and the fourth leading cause of ESKD. Genetic mutations in
PKD1
and
PKD2

, which encode for proteins that regulate differentiation and proliferation of renal tubular epithelial cells, account for approximately 85% and 15% of cases, respectively. More than 90% of mutations are inherited as an autosomal dominant trait, with spontaneous germline mutations accounting for the remaining cases. Early in the disease, there are generally no symptoms. Diagnosis is therefore often delayed in patients without a known family history of ADPKD. The first sign of ADPKD is often hypertension; other early signs and symptoms include hematuria (macroscopic or microscopic), pain or bloating in the back or abdomen, urinary tract infection, or kidney stones.

objective.__html: Diagnose polycystic kidney disease on the basis of clinical and ultrasound findings.

children: A patient is admitted to the ICU with profound azotemia.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has uremic frost. Uremic frost is the dermatologic manifestation of profound azotemia and occurs when urea and other nitrogenous waste products accumulate in sweat and crystallize after evaporation. It is most frequently observed on the areas of skin with eccrine glands and hair (such as the scalp, neck, face, forearms, and chest) and can be easily wiped away. This clinical finding is very uncommon because of the earlier detection and treatment of end-stage kidney disease.
A 33-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus and diabetic kidney disease is evaluated in the emergency department for diabetic ketoacidosis.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following ECG findings is shown?

Hyperkalemia is responsible for the changes seen on this patient's ECG. This ECG demonstrates tall, peaked T waves, and flat P waves, which are characteristic of hyperkalemia. Although the correlation between ECG findings and degree of hyperkalemia may be variable, T-wave peaking often begins with mild to moderate elevations of potassium (5.5-7.0 mEq/L [5.5-7.0 mmol/L]) and tends to persist with more severe hyperkalemia. As potassium levels increase above 7.0 to 8.0 mEq/L (7.0-8.0 mmol/L), P-wave amplitude decreases and the QRS complex widens. With potassium levels above 9.0 to 10.0 mEq/L (9.0-10.0 mmol/L), the waveform will become sinusoidal, and cardiac arrest may follow.

objective.__html: Identify ECG changes characteristic of hyperkalemia.

children: A 46-year-old man is evaluated for pain in his right arm. He has advanced chronic kidney disease and chronic secondary hyperparathyroidism.
A radiograph of the right arm is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is osteitis fibrosa cystica. In this patient's radiograph, the humerus shows changes of osteitis fibrosa cystica characterized by bone cysts and radiolucent lytic areas of the long bones caused by brown tumors. Brown tumors represent a collection of osteoclasts and fibrous material that appears brown secondary to hemosiderin deposition. Other classic radiographic skeletal changes include subperiosteal resorption of bone, most prominently at the phalanges of the hands, as
shown
Osteitis fibrosa cystica is caused by abnormally high bone turnover in secondary hyperparathyroidism and increases the risk of fracture. Patients can be asymptomatic, or they may have bone pain.
A 76-year-old patient is evaluated following a transient ischemic attack.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Funduscopic findings in this patient are consistent with a Hollenhorst plaque, a golden-yellow intra-arterial refractile body characteristic of cholesterol emboli. Cholesterol emboli can occur spontaneously or be precipitated by invasive interventions, such as cardiac catheterization, arteriography, or cardiac or vascular surgery. The clinical manifestations of cholesterol emboli are variable and depend upon the location of the embolic source, extent of the embolization, and whether there is complete or partial occlusion of the vascular bed. This patient's finding may be the result of an ulcerative atherosclerotic plaque located in the internal carotid artery or aortic arch.
